dc:description:
The TFR2 gene encodes transferrin receptor 2, which is predominantly expressed in the liver. This receptor mediates the cellular uptake of transferrin-bound iron and plays a key role in the synthesis of hepcidin (PMID: 36483608).
TFR2 was first implicated in autosomal recessive hemochromatosis type 3 (HH3) in 2000 (Camaschella et al., PMID: 10802645). HH3 is characterized by elevated transferrin saturation, serum ferritin, iron levels, and liver transaminases, along with increased hepatic iron deposition and decreased serum hepcidin. Clinical manifestations include cirrhosis, liver fibrosis, hepatosplenomegaly, cardiomyopathy, hyperpigmentation, hypogonadism, arthritis, diabetes, and hematological abnormalities. A variety of pathogenic variants have been reported in affected individuals, including missense, nonsense, splicing, frameshift variants, and in-frame deletions. This curation includes 25 unrelated probands and 24 unique variants (PMIDs: 10802645, 11313241, 11984516, 12130528, 15685557, 16923517, 18245657, 18450729, 19144662, 23600741, 26029709, 34946929, 35464850). The gene-disease relationship is supported by case-level data and segregation studies, reaching the maximum score of 12 points for case level evidence.
Additional support comes from animal models, expression studies, and functional assays (PMIDs: 10409623, 12134060, 15951546, 18064142, 16935854, 20177050, 20179178, 26408288). Northern blot analysis of human tissues confirmed predominant liver expression of TFR2, and the protein was shown to bind iron-loaded transferrin to facilitate hepatic iron uptake (PMID: 10409623). Multiple TFR2 knockout (KO) mouse models recapitulate the human phenotype, including elevated transferrin saturation, iron levels, ferritin, and hepatic iron accumulation (PMIDs: 12134060, 16935854, 15951546, 20133002, 20179178). These models also exhibit dysregulation of iron metabolism genes coding for hepcidin and ferroportin (PMIDs: 16935854, 20179178, 20133002). Liver-specific knock-in of wild-type TFR2 rescued the iron overload phenotype and restored hepcidin expression (PMID: 20177050). In vitro studies demonstrated that variants identified in HH3 patients led to reduced TFR2 protein accumulation, abnormal glycosylation, retention of mutant proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum and absence of mutant protein on the cell membrane (PMIDs: 26029709, 18094142, 26408288). Although additional experimental evidence exists, the maximum score of 6 points for experimental evidence has already been reached.
In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between TFR2 and autosomal recessive hemochromatosis type 3. This association has been consistently demonstrated in both research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen General Inborn Errors of Metabolism Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date August 22, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description:
1. Transferrin saturation increased in all 3 mice models, the changes in the KO and LCKO-KI mice were significant. Overtime, the iron deposit in liver increased in all 3 models, consistent with the symptoms in patients with HH3.
2. mRNA analysis for 14 days old mice demonstrated decreased expression of hepcidin, BMP6, FPN1 that are associated with increased liver iron concentration; and increased levels of HFE and HJV which could be due to the compensation mechanism. Analysis of the gene expression in 10 weeks old mice showed the gene expression was comparable to WT though hepcidin in KO mice is higher, suggesting complicated mechanisms involved in iron metabolism in liver.
evidence.rdfs:label: Three mice models of inactivating TFR2

evidence.dc:description: In the mice model, saturated transferritin, elevated plasma iron and hepatic iron concentrations and decreased hepcidin level were observed. All of these are symptoms presented by HH3 patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Y250X mice model

evidence.dc:description: Other symptoms reported in HH3 patients were not observed in mice model.
Increased transferritin saturation, ferrtin level and hepatic iron concentration are common symptoms in HH3 patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Knockout mice by deletion of TFR2 exons 2-6

evidence.dc:description: Liver-specific expression of Tfr2 lowers iron levels, increases hepcidin expression, and lowers transferrin saturation in TFT2 245x/245x mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Knockin TFR2 rescue iron overload caused by TFR2 deficiency

evidence.dc:description:
1 .Mutations of TFR2 result in intracellular retention - Immunostaining of the liver cell line transfected with WT or TFR2 mutant Y250X, M172K, Q690P, A621_Q624del demonstarted mislocalization of the mutant TFR2 proteins. The WT TFR2 located in endosome as shown by endosome marker cellubrevin whereas the mutant proteins most likely colocalized with endoplasmic reticulum (ER) marker calnexin. 
2.Western blot of the transfected cell lysates showed the expression of the mutant protein either at the similar levels or mildy lowered in comparison of the WT, suggesitng the mislocolization of the mutant protein was not a consequence of protein translation. 
3.Using the antibody specifically detecting the cell surface localization of the TFR2 protein showed abscent cell surfabce expression of the mutant TFR2, suggesting the mutant resulted in impaired transportation of the TFR2 protein from intracellular ER to cell surface dye to ER retention. 
4.The numbers of cells positive for TFR2 surface expression in the presence of the mutant significantly lower than that of WT groups by flow cytometry.
evidence.rdfs:label: TFR2 mutations resulted in proetin retention

evidence.dc:description:
1. Western blotting of the cell membrane protein in transfection of AVAQ or R379P variants in hepatic cells followed by treatment  cells with holo-transferrin for 24 hours demonstrated TFR2 protein accumulation induced by iron in WT but not in mutant cells, suggesting the mutant protein lost of the normal TFR2 function. 
2. Glycosylation analysis using Endo hf or PNGase to treat the hepatic cells transfected with WT or mutant demonstrated a different glycosylation pattern between WT and mutant, suggesting the variants altered the protein modification, trafficking and function. The decreased level of mutant  protein on cell membrane was due to impaired glycosylation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mutant protein lost the normal function

evidence.dc:description: The basic function of TFR2 is to uptake iron through transferrin in order to maintain iron metabolism. Impaired function of TFR2 reduced the rion metabolism pathway leading to iron overload in liver.
evidence.rdfs:label: The function of TFR2 is to uptake iron via thansferrin

evidence.dc:description: TFR2 is predominantly expressed in liver demonstarted by Northern blotting.
evidence.rdfs:label: TFR2 is predominantly expressed in liver

evidence.dc:description:
1. p.Gly792Arg mutation impairs TFR2 localization to the plasma membrane: mutant was transfected in Huh7 and Hela cells. Compared to WT, mutant protein was abscent on the cell membrane when stained by C-terminal FLAG in non-permeable condition. In the permeable condition and using N-terminal FLAG tag, mutant protein partially co-localized with endoplasmic reticulum instead of locating on the cell membrane. These results suggest the G792R mutant impaired the localization of the TFR2 protein (Fig 3). 
2. Transfection of minigene of construced with WT or mutant in Hela cells. RT-PCR showed that the mutant resutled in aberrant splcing and an inclusion of 7 bp leading to a frameshift (Fig 4B, 4D). 
3. RNA analysis of the patient's cells in the presenc eof inhibitor to block protein translation demonstrated similar aberrant splcing (Fig 4C).

evidence.rdfs:label: II-1
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Negative testing of the HFE gene

evidence.rdfs:label: F2 II-2
evidence.previousTestingDescription: hm H63D, neg HJV, HAMP, SLC40A1

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 6
evidence.previousTestingDescription: neg HFE, SLC40A1: G204S, unknown zygosity

evidence.dc:description: RNA analysis on liver biopsy sample revealed aberrant splicing compared with control that results in exon 4 skipping (Fig 1, 2)
